data.source: Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development Study (ELEMENT)
data.wave_or_subset: Sixth-grade elementary school sample (data collected as part of ELEMENT)
data.notes: Secondary analysis of an existing large-scale dataset; five multiply-imputed data sets were created to handle missing values.

method.description: The authors conducted secondary analyses of the ELEMENT cohort to examine whether speaking a minority home language is associated with better English-as-a-foreign-language achievement. They scaled language tests using item-response theory, created imputed datasets for missing values, and ran multiple regression models (with complex, clustered design) to test associations while controlling for numerous background variables.
steps: Identify language groups using parent and student reports on language(s) spoken at home.
Compute English achievement scores from a 91-item Cloze test (scaled with one-parameter IRT in ConQuest, reported as WLEs).
Compute German reading proficiency from a standardized reading test (IRT-scaled).
Assemble background covariates: general cognitive ability (CFT 4-12R), age, gender, HISEI, parental education, cultural capital (books at home).
Handle missing data via multiple imputation (five datasets) based on a specified background model.

Estimate multiple regression models in MPlus 5.21 (type = complex) to account for clustering within classes: (a) bilingual vs. monolingual; (b) bilingual groups by German proficiency; (c) separate bilingual language groups; with and without background covariates.
Interpret coefficients, significance, and explained variance (R²) across models.
method.models: Multiple linear regression models with cluster-robust standard errors (students nested in classes); comparisons include dummy variables for bilingual status or specific language groups; additional covariates entered hierarchically.
method.outcome_variable: English language achievement (Cloze test WLE score, mean 100, SD 20)
method.independent_variables: Bilingual status; specific bilingual language group dummies; German reading proficiency; German proficiency level dummies
method.control_variables: General cognitive abilities (CFT score), age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (books at home)
method.tools_software: ConQuest (IRT scaling); MPlus 5.21 (regression with multiple imputation and complex sampling)

results.summary: After controlling for cognitive, demographic and socio-economic background factors, bilingualism was positively associated with English achievement. The strength of this association varied by instructional-language proficiency and by specific bilingual group. Chinese-German and Polish-German students showed the largest advantages (~7 WLE points). Turkish-German and a heterogeneous bilingual group also showed positive trends once German proficiency was controlled. Arabic-German students performed similarly to monolingual peers after adjustment. Overall, German reading proficiency was the strongest single predictor of English achievement.
